messages.text: Anyone have any experience running Julia 'in anger' for a microservice/microservices? And if so, have you run into many/any issues with packages leaking memory? Finding that Python libraries seem to be pretty bad in that regard

messages.text: I looked into LSP for different IDEs... It seems like the communication between the LSP and IDE features is based on JSON? Isn't that extremely inefficient to send text across and then parse the text? Is it really the best communication "protocol" we have between two processes?

messages.text: Dex also uses the effect system to pickup parallelism in the use of the loop constructs, so it's encoded in the type system somehow without having brittle compiler heuristics..or that's my understanding  <https://twitter.com/apaszke/status/1350854130634543110?s=19|https://twitter.com/apaszke/status/1350854130634543110?s=19>

root.text: And discussion btwn dex and futhark people <https://twitter.com/sigkill_dk/status/1343580541338136576>

attachments.fallback: <https://twitter.com/sigkill_dk|@sigkill_dk>: I rewrote a handful of Dex programs in Futhark and wrote about the experience: <https://futhark-lang.org/blog/2020-12-28-futhark-and-dex.html>
attachments.text: I rewrote a handful of Dex programs in Futhark and wrote about the experience: <https://futhark-lang.org/blog/2020-12-28-futhark-and-dex.html>

elements.text: And discussion btwn dex and futhark people

attachments.fallback: <https://twitter.com/apaszke|@apaszke>: <https://twitter.com/AriKatz20|@AriKatz20> It all depends on the loop body, or more concretely on its type! If it‚Äôs a pure loop then it‚Äôs a simple map. If it has an Accum effect then it‚Äôs a reduction/scan and can still be efficiently parallelized. If it has the State effect then it has to be sequential.
attachments.text: <https://twitter.com/AriKatz20|@AriKatz20> It all depends on the loop body, or more concretely on its type! If it‚Äôs a pure loop then it‚Äôs a simple map. If it has an Accum effect then it‚Äôs a reduction/scan and can still be efficiently parallelized. If it has the State effect then it has to be sequential.

elements.text: Dex also uses the effect system to pickup parallelism in the use of the loop constructs, so it's encoded in the type system somehow without having brittle compiler heuristics..or that's my understanding
https://twitter.com/apaszke/status/1350854130634543110?s=19

messages.text:
I'm sure there's a rich and important historical context of the pardons the US president can make, but I'll never understand the concept. This is not Trump bashing, or aimed at any political party, so I hope it's not "politics". It's not even "America is stupid" either, each country has their quirks. This just seems like such a weird thing a country's leader can do
> The <http://www.cnn.com/2021/01/20/politics/lil-wayne-kodak-black-trump/index.html|rapper Lil Wayne received a pardon> after pleading guilty to a gun possession charge in Miami. Another rapper, Kodak Black, received a commutation after he pleaded guilty to a weapons charge.
:confusedpuppy:

attachments.title: Trump grants clemency to rappers Lil Wayne and Kodak Black in final flurry of presidential power
attachments.text: The White House announced early Wednesday that President Donald Trump has granted a pardon to rapper Lil Wayne and a commutation to rapper Kodak Black, two of the raft of pardons and commutations on his final day in office.
attachments.fallback: CNN: Trump grants clemency to rappers Lil Wayne and Kodak Black in final flurry of presidential power

elements.text: I'm sure there's a rich and important historical context of the pardons the US president can make, but I'll never understand the concept. This is not Trump bashing, or aimed at any political party, so I hope it's not "politics". It's not even "America is stupid" either, each country has their quirks. This just seems like such a weird thing a country's leader can do
The
rapper Lil Wayne received a pardon
after pleading guilty to a gun possession charge in Miami. Another rapper, Kodak Black, received a commutation after he pleaded guilty to a weapons charge.

messages.text: what the hell is this obsession people have with 0 vs 1 based indexing? It's as if using 1-based indexing is like being in a mission impossible movie

elements.text: what the hell is this obsession people have with 0 vs 1 based indexing? It's as if using 1-based indexing is like being in a mission impossible movie

messages.text: I don't think people are particularly obsessed. It's just that it's one of those things where it's easy for everyone to have an opinion, while at the same time being an issue with pros and cons on both sides. So everyone can chime in, and will chime in

elements.text: I don't think people are particularly obsessed. It's just that it's one of those things where it's easy for everyone to have an opinion, while at the same time being an issue with pros and cons on both sides. So everyone can chime in, and will chime in

messages.text: I don't know, people seem pretty obsessed to me.  In my opinion, any time you have to do something complicated with indexing, 0-based is better, but most of the time 1-based, is a little more convenient.  Therefore 0-based is better.  Don't really see it as that big a deal though, especially when `Base` mercifully has built-in functions usch as `mod1`

elements.text: I don't know, people seem pretty obsessed to me. Don't really see it as that big a deal though, especially when
Base
mercifully has built-in functions usch as
mod1

messages.text: can you share what sort of tasks it involves? is it mathy like project euler?

elements.text: can you share what sort of tasks it involves? is it mathy like project euler?

messages.text: It's just more like typical CS'y interview questions

elements.text: It's just more like typical CS'y interview questions

messages.text: its like CS stuff, little bit of math problems. Can only use 2.7 std libs (no numpy or anything). Some of the problems aren't super hard - but... What makes them hard is you have to pass hidden test cases. They also make timeout limits - so like if you write a recursive function and they have a test case with 3000 digits, lol it's gonna pop

elements.text: its like CS stuff, little bit of math problems. Can only use 2.7 std libs (no numpy or anything). Some of the problems aren't super hard - but... What makes them hard is you have to pass hidden test cases. They also make timeout limits - so like if you write a recursive function and they have a test case with 3000 digits, lol it's gonna pop

messages.text: Some of the questions aren't very clear either

elements.text: Some of the questions aren't very clear either

messages.text:
but some of the problems are genuinely challenging and seem to require some abstract thinking. So far I've seen things related too: basic data structures, control flow, number theory, graph theory/stats on graphs, dynamic programming, and geometry/route planning
the most frusterating thing is - some of these you can solve in like 30 lines of clean basic julia but in base python they might be more like 150+LOC. Or even if they just let your write C it'd be easier.

elements.text:
but some of the problems are genuinely challenging and seem to require some abstract thinking. So far I've seen things related too: basic data structures, control flow, number theory, graph theory/stats on graphs, dynamic programming, and geometry/route planning
the most frusterating thing is - some of these you can solve in like 30 lines of clean basic julia but in base python they might be more like 150+LOC. Or even if they just let your write C it'd be easier.

messages.text: Not to beat a dead horse on the M1 Macs..., but some folks in my field are having a minor <https://gist.github.com/Houstonwp/b905920baa48891117ce9523420c1ab2#gistcomment-3602910|benchmarking game>. I though I was being a little conservative running benchmarks on my new Macbook Air with Julia 1.6 running on Rosetta2 (ie non-native). I just ran them on my i9-9900k desktop. And the Macbook is 0-20% _faster_ than the desktop on these simple numerical benchmarks

elements.text: Not to beat a dead horse on the M1 Macs..., but some folks in my field are having a minor
benchmarking game

. I though I was being a little conservative running benchmarks on my new Macbook Air with Julia 1.6 running on Rosetta2 (ie non-native). I just ran them on my i9-9900k desktop. And the Macbook is 0-20%
faster
than the desktop on these simple numerical benchmarks

Crossposting from general,
since I figure this is where people wanting to procrastinate go.

attachments.fallback:
[January 24th, 2021 7:10 PM] jonas.isensee: Hi!

Anyone interested in data compression and JLD2 ?
I'm working on a PR to bring new compression libs to JLD2 along with better control.
<https://github.com/JuliaIO/JLD2.jl/pull/264>

Testing it out and API feedback would be valuable help!
attachments.text:
Hi!

Anyone interested in data compression and JLD2 ?
I'm working on a PR to bring new compression libs to JLD2 along with better control.
<https://github.com/JuliaIO/JLD2.jl/pull/264>

Testing it out and API feedback would be valuable help!

messages.text: This article talks about how modern silicon now often includes a diversity of hardware (CPU, GPU, "AI") and also discusses the "OneAPI" project from Intel that aims to allow a single API for programming all the hardware.  <https://easyperf.net/blog/2020/12/30/Computing-Industry-2020>

messages.text:
Full disclosure: didn't actually see this talk, but was happy and surprised to see other examples of AD in the wild.
<https://icfp20.sigplan.org/details/ocaml-2020-papers/12/AD-OCaml-Algorithmic-Differentiation-for-OCaml>

attachments.title: AD-OCaml: Algorithmic Differentiation for OCaml (OCaml 2020) - ICFP 2020
attachments.text: The OCaml Users and Developers Workshop brings together industrial users of OCaml with academics and hackers who are working on extending the language, type system, and tools. Previous editions have been co-located with ICFP 2012 in Copenhagen, ICFP 2013 in Boston, ICFP 2014 in Gothenburg, ICFP 2015 in Vancouver, ICFP 2016 in Nara, ICFP 2017 in Oxford, ICFP 2018 in St Louis, and ICFP 2019 in Berlin, following the OCaml Meetings in Paris in 2010 and 2011. OCaml 2020 will be held on August 28th, 2020 in New Jersey, USA, co-located with ICFP 2020.
attachments.fallback: AD-OCaml: Algorithmic Differentiation for OCaml (OCaml 2020) - ICFP 2020

elements.text: Full disclosure: didn't actually see this talk, but was happy and surprised to see other examples of AD in the wild.

messages.text:
Authy vs Yubikey? I wonder if someone has comments if both options are ok for MFA. I just created a new AWS account, and I wanted to enable MFA for it.
I spent some time learning what Yubikey does, and wondered which one to get for a mac and ipad, and then I figured out that Authy is much easier to use.. And I don‚Äôt have to shell out ‚Ç¨ for a physical thing that‚Äôs cumbersome.

messages.text:
<https://www.theverge.com/2021/1/27/22252261/google-maps-electric-vehicle-charging-station-ai>
Am I wrong or is this literally not AI technology? The article mentions their using graph theory to solve the problem of routing among electric charging stations. But that's not "AI" in the sense that it's not using neural networks or anything like that. If this is AI then like any program that solves any problem is AI?

attachments.title: Google‚Äôs using AI to plan electric car trips because EV charging is still a nightmare
attachments.text: Google wants to help solve the EV charging "puzzle," which is a polite way of describing it.
attachments.fallback: The Verge: Google‚Äôs using AI to plan electric car trips because EV charging is still a nightmare
